item.title: Superficial Venous Disease
item.description: Background Varicose veins are dilated and tortuous veins Superficial veins drain into the deep veins through the deep muscle fascia via the perforator veins Valves prevent back flow of blood from deep to superficial veins Varicose veins develop when the superficial vein valves become incompetent, leading to the reflux and pooling of blood in the superficial veins The great saphenous vein, short saphenous vein or perforators may be affected A saphena varix occurs when there is dilatation of the great saphenous vein at the junction with the femoral vein Causes: Primary: usually idiopathic Secondary: intravascular disease (DVT); extravascular disease (pelvic mass) Risk factors Non modifiable: Age; female gender; family history Modifiable: pregnancy, previous DVT, previous trauma to the lower limb Presentation Symptoms: pain (dull ache, heaviness or burning); pain worse after standing and relieved with leg elevation; nocturnal leg cramps; itching Signs: haemosiderin staining; venous eczema; oedema; lipodermatosclerosis; ulceration Complications: ulceration; bleeding; thrombophlebitis; DVT; reduced quality of life Diagnosis Clinical diagnosis Duplex ultrasound can identify location of varicosities and degree of reflux to guide treatment Duplex ultrasound can assess the deep venous system.

item.title: Vascular history
item.description: Summary Presenting complaint Pain: SOCRATES Aneurysm: Usually asymptomatic but patients may report abdominal or back pain Peripheral arterial disease: A cramping type pain in the buttock or calf which occurs with exertion, usually at a consistent distance. The pain is relieved by rest. Ask how far the patient can walk before they have pain/need to stop (claudication distance). In critical limb ischaemia, individuals describe rest pain or night pain, which is relieved by hanging the foot over the edge of the bed.
